Description: Terracotta model boat. A model of a Nile boat, with high knobbed and pointed stern and rounded bows, decked and with a rounded double-arched cabin, presumably representing a reed structure: the whole boat may be of papyrus construction. In front of the cabin is a ladder-patterned crosspiece, and square impressions near the bow and the stern may be hatchways. The underside rounds down to a flattish bottom of oval shape decorated with longitudinal grooves, with an extension under the stern and two extensions towards the bow. A hole is pierced vertically at the bow, and another, perhaps a firing-vent, enters the front of the cabin. The hole in the bow may show that this is a pull-along toy. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous light-brown Nile silt (perhaps with a mixing of a light-coloured marl clay), containing some white inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: British School of Archaeology, Egypt
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Near and not unlike: Breccia 1926: pl. lxxiii:9, from Theadelphia; Djuric 1995: 28, C 63 and 64 (C 63 is probably a pullalong toy); Dunand 1990: no. 1008, dated Roman period; El-Khachab 1978, pl. xvi:832, from Sakha in the north Delta; Göttlicher 1978: 22–3, nos 292–4, from the Fayum, and 298, also pl. 56:297; Göttlicher 1985: 97, fig. 54; Hayes 1980: no. 410; Kaufmann 1913: fig. 134; Perdrizet 1921: no. 301. More complex: Breccia 1934: no. 448; Weber 1914: no. 469, from Saqqara. Bibliog. Göttlicher 1978: no. 521.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3538)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
